content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved. Quite easy challenge, but it's good to practise quickness. And it's your first contribution, so this also is to encourage !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Although I'm pretty sure there is already a challenge like this in the system, It won't hurt if we have 2 versions of it. But I'm not 100% sure there is one in the system, so yours must get in.
Like @lopidav stated, each validator needs to be similar (but not identical) to its previous test case. That way, a user that writes his code like so: "if input()=='80 85 90 100 105 115' print('PUZdis')" and so on for every test case (which is visible to him/her), his code will still fail because of the invisible validators. Also, because it's your first contribution, I'll approve it. Please contribute more and upvote and approve/reject other's work too. Good luck :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A lil bit too easy for my taste but guidelines say that 'too easy' is not a reason for coc puzzle rejection

Some corrections that I've done:
Changed the input/output descriptions a little but it doesn't matter since players will not see it.
Changed stab so it reads only one string and changed this string to be 255 chars long since you have a validator that has input 233 chars long.

AnasShami, there is some stuff that you might not know:

There are two types of tests: actual tests and validators.
Players will see actual testes (their input/output) but they will not see validators. It's done so players can't just hardcode test cases and get 100%.
But if the player's code would pass all of the testes but it'll not get 100% on the validators then your puzzle will get poorly rated and will be filtered out.
So you need to make each validator similar to the previous test.
Also, you can let validators be unnamed since they will be ever visible only on this page.

Specifically in the reverse mode players also can't see the statement, input/output descriptions, and constraints. So you put some placeholder in those fields if you're making a puzzle exclusively for the Reverse.

Hi,
I tested this in the IDE. You have a MAJOR problem there mate.

The problem is:
you are taking 2 input lines instead of 1 as you describe in your Goal statement.
I mean, this:
"
# Auto-generated code below aims at helping you parse
# the standard input according to the problem statement.

nstring = input()
string = input()
"
And sure enough, this leads to a:
"
Errors
EOFError: EOF when reading a line
at Answer.py. in <module> on line 8
"

So please fix that before me or anyone should approve your contribution.
Comment me here after you fixed it and I'll approve your clash.

Other than that, this is a fun and quick little clash. Nice.
For the input, do you mean numbers separated instead of spirited?

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Honestly, many of this type of puzzle already exist. Need something more original
Makes test cases and validators different

> https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines
> Contributions must be original. (for all games but Clash of Code)

Yep, pretty sure this is due to your
*Stub generator input*
remove the 2nd line
"
read string:string(128)
"
And you should be good
